title: Aurora Australis over Concordia station
summary: The Aurora Australis, photographed over Concordia station in July 2025, during the ongoing solar activity maximum, the peak of the Sun's 11-year cycle.
detailed_news: Aurora Australis appears when charged particles from the Sun are guided by Earth’s magnetic field towards the polar regions. Concordia station, perched high on Antarctica’‘Dome C plateau, is one of the most remote research outposts on Earth. Each year, ESA sponsors a medical doctor to live and work at Concordia.

title: Webb investigates complex heart of a cosmic butterfly
summary: The NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has revealed new details in the core of the Butterfly Nebula, NGC 6302. From the dense, dusty torus that surrounds the star hidden at the centre of the nebula to its outflowing jets, the Webb observations reveal many new discoveries that paint a never-before-seen portrait of a dynamic and structured planetary nebula.
detailed_news: Butterfly Nebula is located about 3400 light-years away in the constellation Scorpius. It is one of the best-studied planetary nebulas in our galaxy. This stunning nebula was previously imaged by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. Now, Webb has captured a new view of this nebula. Team also spotted light emitted by carbon-based molecules known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. They form flat, ring-like structures, much like the honeycomb shapes found in beehives. This may be the first-ever evidence of PAHs forming in a oxygen-rich planetary nebula.

The contracts will support the launches of the ISISpace Cassini and Infinite Orbits Tom & Jerry missions, both set to fly aboard Isar aerospace rockets from 2026 onwards. Each launch opportunity would carry a maximum award of €5 million.

It allows European companies and institutions to test and prove new products and applications in space. It encourages the use of new European launchers. Testing prototypes in space provides valuable insight for research projects and unlocks the market potential of commercial applications.

A launch try Sunday was called off because of trouble with ground equipment. A second attempt Monday was blocked by cloudy weather. title: Google’s AI model just nailed the forecast for the strongest Atlantic storm this year
summary: If they improve further, AI weather models may very well become the gold standard.
detailed_news: Google unveiled a new model designed specifically to forecast the tracks and intensity of tropical cyclones. The "Weather Lab" model for cyclones was a bit of an unknown for meteorologists at its launch. Google's model beat the "official" track forecast from the National Hurricane Center. The fact that Google's model beat the consensus models is significant. From a forecast standpoint, the period of three to five days out is the most important. This is when important decisions about evacuations and other hurricane preparations need to be made. If these models improve further, they may very well become the gold standard for certain types of weather prediction.

detailed_news: NASA Stennis has its own protected airspace, similar to how airports control the skies around them. It operates two main airspace zones – a propulsion testing area extending from ground level up to 12,000 feet for safely testing rocket engines. The centerpiece of the NASA Stennis marine range is its extensive 7.5-mile canal system. The NASA Stennis federal city already hosts more than 50 federal, state, academic, public, and private aerospace, technology, and research organizations. “NASA Stennis is open for business, and we want to provide a user-friendly range for operators to test vehicles,” Peterson said.

title: Gaia proves our skies are filled with chains of starry gatherings
summary: In the past decade, the European Space Agency’s Gaia mission has revealed the nature, history, and behaviour of billions of stars. Our pioneering stargazer has reshaped our view of the skies around us like no other, revealing that star clusters are more connected than expected over vast distances.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s Gaia mission has revealed the nature, history, and behaviour of billions of stars. Since it opened its eyes in 2014, Gaia has mapped how different stars zip through space and pinpointed their whereabouts more precisely than ever. The telescope has watched whether they shrink and swell, spotted surprising ‘ starquakes ’, monitored how stars grow, evolve, and crystallise as they die. Gaia has revolutionised our view of the solar neighbourhood, allowing scientists to comprehensively map all the stars and interstellar ‘stuff’ near the Sun in a way they were unable to do before. Scientists have also applied Artificial Intelligence (AI) to Gaia data, using algorithms and machine learning approaches to pinpoint new cluster members and subgroups of stars. In this way, Gaia has pushed us to rethink how we hunt for stellar groups.  Gaia has shown that structures resembling streams, beads, strings, pearls, snakes, rings, or filaments of stars are reasonably common in young cluster formation. It has also revealed that large-scale galactic dynamics influence how young star clusters form in the first place. Thanks to Gaia, open clusters are no longer seen as isolated entities but as dynamically evolving structures, slowly dissolving into our galaxy. Gaia has now completed its sky-scanning observations and, as of March 2025, is quietly orbiting the Sun in its retirement orbit. The vast majority of data collected by the spacecraft is yet to be released, with a couple of huge data releases planned by the end of the decade. Scientists are already using Gaia’s treasure trove of released observations to explore billions of stars and objects in our galaxy and beyond.

title: Vulcan Begins Operational Missions
summary: On August 12, 2025 at 8:56 p.m. EDT (0056 UTC), United Launch Alliance successfully launched its Vulcan Centaur VC4S vehicle from Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station for the USSF-106 mission.
detailed_news: On August 12, 2025 at 8:56 p.m. EDT (0056 UTC), United Launch Alliance successfully launched its Vulcan Centaur VC4S vehicle. This was the third overall flight of the Vulcan rocket but its first to carry national security payloads. The ascent was nominal, despite an SRB nozzle anomaly on flight 2 which led to a lengthy stand down. Vulcan successfully launched USSF-106 from Cape Canaveral on April 4, 2025. The launch was part of the second round of the National Security Space Launch program. The program seeks to distribute vital government payloads across industry to prevent potential bottlenecks. The path to operational Vulcan flights has been marred with challenges, with the company encountering several key issues.

title: From NASA Citizen Scientist to Astronaut Training: An Interview with Benedetta Facini
summary: Titans Space Industries, a commercial space company, selected a new cohort of astronaut candidates this spring – and among them is NASA citizen scientist, Benedetta Facini. We asked […]
detailed_news: Benedetta Facini is a NASA citizen scientist. She has participated in not one, but many NASA citizen science projects. Facini was selected as an Astronaut Candidate by the commercial space company, Titans Space Industries. She shares her advice for other citizen scientists and people who want to become astronauts. For aspiring astronauts, my advice is to gain as much experience as possible. Academic results are important but hands-on skills, teamwork, adaptability, and real experiences are also important. Don’t be afraid to ask for help and interact with other colleagues because the goal of the NASA Citizen Science program is international collaboration.

summary: A Washington state high school student with a passion for art, space exploration, and a curiosity about the possibility of life on other planets earned the grand prize for the 2025 NASA Student Art Contest. title: Astronomers Map Stellar ‘Polka Dots’ Using NASA’s TESS, Kepler
summary: Scientists have devised a new method for mapping the spottiness of distant stars by using observations from NASA missions of orbiting planets crossing their stars’ faces. The model builds on a technique researchers have used for decades to study star spots. By improving astronomers’ understanding of spotty stars, the new model — called StarryStarryProcess — […]
detailed_news: Scientists have devised a new method for mapping the spottiness of distant stars. Model builds on a technique researchers have used for decades to study star spots. By improving astronomers’ understanding of spotty stars, the new model — called StarryStarryProcess — can help discover more about planetary atmospheres and potential habitability. Astronomers think the planet is a gas giant about five times bigger than Earth and 32 times its mass. The StarryStarryProcess analysis suggests that the planet’s cool, dim star — called TOI 3384 — has concentrations of spots at its north pole. Pandora, a small satellite developed through NASA's Astrophysics Pioneers Program, will study the atmospheres of exoplanets.

title: Harmonized Landsat and Sentinel-2: Collaboration Drives Innovation
summary: Introduction Landsat, a joint program of NASA and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), has been an invaluable tool for monitoring changes in Earth’s land surface for over 50 years. Researchers use instruments on Landsat satellites to monitor decades-long trends, including urbanization and agricultural expansion, as well as short-term dynamics, including water use and disaster recovery. […]
detailed_news: Harmonized Landsat and Sentinel-2 (HLS) project is a NASA initiative that created a seamless product from the Operational Land Imager (OLI) and Multi-Spectral Instrument (MSI) HLS Version 2.0 (V2.0) is the most recent version of these data and had a global median repeat frequency of 1.6 days in 2022. HLS data are available for download on NASA Earthdata: HLSL30v3.0 and HLSS30v4.0 . HLS V2.0 provides data at a spatial resolution of 30 m (98 ft) with near-global coverage from 2013 onward. HLS V1.4 covered about 30% of the global land area, providing data on North America and other select locations. The increased frequency of observations improved the ability of the scientific community to track disaster recovery. On average, DIST-ALERT is made available on LP DAAC within six hours of when new HLS data is available. Currently, the dataset does not provide attribution to disturbances. HLS V2.0 data are also better at identifying disturbances in cloudy ecosystems than other individual alert systems.

title: ESA data records help underpin climate change report
summary: According to the newly released 35th State of the Climate report, 2024 saw record highs in greenhouse gas concentrations, global land and ocean temperatures, sea levels, and ocean heat content. detailed_news: The 35th State of the Climate report has been published by the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. 2024 saw record highs in greenhouse gas concentrations, global land and ocean temperatures, sea levels, and ocean heat content. Glaciers suffered their largest annual ice loss on record. Data records from ESA’s Climate Change Initiative helped underpin these findings. Permafrost stores nearly 1700 billion tonnes of frozen and thawing carbon. Anthropogenic warming threatens to release an unknown quantity of this carbon to the atmosphere. Sometimes permafrost can thaw rapidly, but scientists are unsure why and what these abrupt thaws mean in terms of feedback loops.

title: Juice team resolves anomaly on approach to Venus
summary: The European Space Agency’s Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice) is on track for its gravity-assist flyby at Venus on 31 August, following the successful resolution of a spacecraft communication anomaly that temporarily severed contact with Earth.
detailed_news: Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (Juice) is on track for its gravity-assist flyby at Venus on 31 August. The issue emerged during a routine ground station pass on 16 July. It temporarily disrupted Juice’s ability to transmit information about its health and status (telemetry) Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer, ‘Juice’, is humankind’s next bold mission to the outer Solar System. It will make detailed observations of gas giant Jupiter and its three large ocean-bearing moons – Ganymede, Callisto and Europa. It has an eight-year cruise with flybys of Earth and Venus to slingshot it to Jupiter.

Docking at the forward port of the Harmony module is anticipated on Monday, Aug. 25, at 7:30 a.m. EDT.

title: NASA Science, Cargo Launch on 33rd SpaceX Resupply Mission to Station
summary: Following a successful launch of NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission, new scientific experiments and cargo for the agency are bound for the International Space Station. The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, carrying more than 5,000 pounds of supplies to the orbiting laboratory, lifted off at 2:45 a.m. EDT on Sunday, on the company’s Falcon 9 rocket […]
detailed_news: Following a successful launch of NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission, new scientific experiments and cargo for the agency are bound for the International Space Station. The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, carrying more than 5,000 pounds of supplies to the orbiting laboratory, lifted off at 2:45 a.m. EDT on Sunday, on the company’s Falcon 9 rocket […]

title: Starship prepares to launch Flight 10 in penultimate Block 2 test
summary:
SpaceX has not experienced much success with the Block 2 version of Starship since its…
The post Starship prepares to launch Flight 10 in penultimate Block 2 test appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has not experienced much success with the Block 2 version of Starship since its introduction earlier this year. Ship 37 aims to break this streak during Flight 10, which is set to launch no earlier than August 24 at 6:30 p.m. Central Daylight Time. This journey started with Ship 33 and Booster 14 for Flight 7 on January 16, 2025. The second Block 2 ship to fly was Ship 34 paired with Booster 15. Ship 36 experienced an anomaly on June 18, which resulted in the loss of the ship on the Masseys static fire test stand. This caused a pressurization problem in the payload bay and in the methane tank. Ship 35 reentered in an uncontrolled manner and was lost without completing any primary objectives. Booster 16 was static fire tested on June 6, when it was slated to fly with Ship 36.  Starship Flight 10 is currently set for no earlier than Aug 24 at 6:30 pm Central Daylight Time with a one-hour launch window. The only significant difference is that Booster 16 will have a boost back burn that is 10 seconds longer compared to Flight 9. As for trajectory, this will once again be a suborbital ballistic trajectory with Ship 37 set to splashdown in the Indian Ocean.

title: Live coverage: NASA, SpaceX to launch Falcon 9 rocket, Dragon spacecraft on CRS-33 from Cape Canaveral
summary: This will be the first Cargo Dragon flight featuring a modified trunk that allows it to perform multiple orbital boosts of the International Space Station. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 2:45 a.m. EDT (0645 UTC).
detailed_news: The Dragon spacecraft set to launch in the predawn hours of Sunday morning features a new propulsion system inside its unpressurized trunk. This addition will allow the spacecraft to boost the orbit of the space station, keeping it in its desired orbit. SpaceX will launch the mission using its Falcon 9 first stage booster with the tail number B1090, which will fly for a seventh time. SpaceX's Dragon capsule heading for the International Space Station carrying more than 4,800 pounds of supplies and experiments. SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket is set for liftoff from Cape Canaveral on Monday, heading due east over the Atlantic Ocean to deliver the Telstar 18 VANTAGE communications satellite into orbit around 32 minutes later.

title: NASA Tests Tools to Assess Drone Safety Over Cities
summary: A future with advanced air mobility aircraft populating the skies will require the U.S. to implement enhanced preflight planning that can mitigate potential risks well before takeoff – and NASA is working to develop the tools to make that happen.  Preflight planning is critical to ensuring safety in the complex, high-risk environments of the future […]
detailed_news: NASA and aviation safety company ResilienX Inc. demonstrated how these tools can be integrated into commercial systems. Timely, predictive, and up-to-date risk assessment within a single platform makes it much easier for drone or air taxi operators to check flight plans. Allowing operators to perform these tasks quickly reduces the safety risk to flight passengers as well as humans on the ground.

title: NASA Shares Final Contenders for Artemis II Moon Mascot Design Contest
summary: NASA is down to 25 finalists for the Artemis II zero gravity indicator set to fly with the mission’s crew around the Moon and back next year. Astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch of NASA, and CSA (Canadian Space Agency) astronaut Jeremy Hansen will soon select one of the finalist designs to join […]
detailed_news: NASA is down to 25 finalists for the Artemis II zero gravity indicator set to fly with the mission’s crew around the Moon and back next year. Astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch of NASA, and CSA (Canadian Space Agency) astronaut Jeremy Hansen will soon select one of the finalist designs to join them inside the Orion spacecraft.

title: UK Space Agency Hires Consultants to Explain the UK Space Sector
summary:
The UK Space Agency has commissioned Frazer-Nash Consultancy to review the nation’s capacity to deliver on in-situ resource utilisation capabilities. According to the agency, the results of the study will be used to “inform future activities in this area.” In an 18 August press release, Surrey-based Frazer-Nash Consultancy explained that the study will examine the […]
The post UK Space Agency Hires Consultants to Explain the UK Space Sector appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The UK Space Agency has commissioned Frazer-Nash Consultancy to review the nation’s capacity to deliver on in-situ resource utilisation capabilities. The results of the study will be used to “inform future activities in this area” As a “first step,” Frazers has asked companies developing ISRU technology or solutions to complete a 10-minute survey before 17 October.

title: Epic Research Can Help Mars Missions
summary: The parachute of the Enhancing Parachutes by Instrumenting the Canopy, or EPIC, test experiment deploys following an air launch from an Alta X drone on June 4, 2025, at NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California. NASA researchers are developing technology to make supersonic parachutes safer and more reliable for delivering instruments and payloads […]
detailed_news: NASA researchers are developing technology to make supersonic parachutes safer and more reliable for delivering instruments and payloads to Mars. The flight tests were a first step toward filling gaps in computer models to improve the parachutes. This work could also open the door to future partnerships, including with the aerospace and auto racing industries.

title: NASA’s Bennu Samples Reveal Complex Origins, Dramatic Transformation
summary: Asteroid Bennu, sampled by NASA’s OSIRIS-REx mission in 2023, is a mixture of dust that formed in our solar system, organic matter from interstellar space, and pre-solar system stardust. Its unique and varied contents were dramatically transformed over time by interactions with water and exposure to the harsh space environment. These insights come from a trio of newly published papers based on the analysis of Bennu samples by scientists at NASA and other institutions.
detailed_news: Asteroid Bennu is a mixture of dust that formed in our solar system, organic matter from interstellar space, and pre-solar system stardust. Its unique and varied contents were dramatically transformed over time by interactions with water and exposure to the harsh space environment. These insights come from a trio of newly published papers based on the analysis of Bennu samples. Asteroids provide a record of the solar system’s history. Some types of asteroids burn up in the atmosphere and never make it to the ground. The next samples NASA expects to help unravel our solar system's story will be Moon rocks returned by the Artemis III astronauts.

title: Lunar Environment Structural Test Rig
summary: The Lunar Environment Structural Test Rig simulates the intense cold of the lunar night, ranging from 40 Kelvin (K) to 125 K while maintaining a vacuum environment. This creates a tool by which scientists and engineers can test materials, electronics, and flight hardware for future Moon and Mars missions, characterizing their behaviors at these temperatures while also validating their ability to meet design requirements.
detailed_news: LESTR simulates the intense cold of the lunar night, ranging from 40 Kelvin (K) to 125 K. It uses a cryocooler to reject heat and bring the test section to any point desired by the test engineer. LESTR enables safe, accurate, and cost-effective testing of materials and hardware.
